Chapter 15: Generating the Mind of Enlightenment, Chapter on Generating the Mind of Enlightenment. Having fulfilled the matter of giving, being a relative of all sentient beings, never for a single moment not in accord with the mind of compassion.

The compassionate mind of the bodhisattva universally relates to all, there is none that it does not relate to. Because the compassionate mind is universal, later when becoming a Buddha one attains the unobstructed knowledge of all kinds.
Because of the compassionate mind, one abandons the liberation of the Å›rÄvakas and generates the mind of enlightenment.
This initial single thought, only the Buddha knows its extent, let alone the practice of enlightenment and the bliss of liberation?
From the very first single thought of generating the mind of enlightenment, it is like the gold of the great earth, the earth and gold are not comparable.
When first generating the mind, one is able to purify all bonds and afflictions, and attract all merits.
Enlightenment is the fruit of generating the mind, seeking happiness for all sentient beings.
Those who have given rise to the bodhi mind but have not yet made vows asked:
What is liberation like?
For what reasons do they ask?
Because those who have given rise to the mind are like those who have come from liberation, they ask:
What are the characteristics of liberation?
Is it known by going to liberation?
Or does liberation come?
Those who have made vows replied:
The joy and happiness of giving rise to the bodhi mind is like liberation, therefore it can be known.
Those who wish to make offerings to all Buddhas should give rise to the bodhi mind;
Those who wish to repay the Buddha's kindness should give rise to a firm and solid bodhi mind.
Apart from giving rise to the bodhi mind, there is no other Dharma that can reach bodhi.
If there is no bodhi mind, one cannot attain Buddhahood. If one cannot attain Buddhahood, one cannot save and deliver sentient beings.
Those who wish to bestow immeasurable great joy upon all sentient beings should give rise to the bodhi mind.
Why is it so?
The mind of enlightenment is the cause of happiness for all sentient beings.
All forms are not apart from the four great elements, and all happy events are not apart from the mind of enlightenment.
Alas!
How is it that you are not afraid of the suffering of birth and death, but are afraid of the fearless mind of enlightenment?
If you wish to put an end to the suffering of all sentient beings, there is nothing better than giving rise to the mind of enlightenment.
Giving rise to the mind of enlightenment is the initial cause of putting an end [to suffering], and through the initial end [of suffering] one attains the unsurpassed end [of suffering].

Obtaining the benefits of wealth and treasures is not as good as obtaining the benefits of merit, obtaining the benefits of merit is not as good as obtaining the benefits of wisdom, and obtaining the benefits of wisdom is not as good as obtaining the benefits of the mind of enlightenment.
If one is negligent and forgets to think of the mind of enlightenment, one is no different from an animal.
How is it that you now do not give rise to a compassionate mind?
You should know that a compassionate mind is precisely great enlightenment.
If you wish to head towards the wisdom of the Buddha, you should give rise to the mind of enlightenment.
Those who are obstructed by afflictions cannot give rise to the mind of liberation, and those who are obstructed by karmic retribution cannot give rise to the mind of enlightenment.
What is wrong practice?
What is right practice?
Those who are dragged by craving for existence and take the four formless [absorptions] as liberation are called those of wrong practice;
Those who give rise to the mind of enlightenment and cultivate the eightfold noble path are called those of right practice.

Those who practice giving in order to obtain abundant rewards, those who practice compassion in order to obtain happy rewards, and those who wish to rescue and bring peace and happiness to sentient beings should firmly give rise to the mind of enlightenment.
There are three things that are difficult to obtain for those who do not cultivate merit:
First, they cannot get close to good friends;
Second, they cannot be compassionate and detached;
Third, they cannot respect and esteem the wisdom of the Buddha.
Those who have not given rise to the mind of enlightenment should give rise to the mind, and those who have given rise to the mind of enlightenment will attain omniscience.

Chapter 16: The Chapter on the Excellence of Merits. Some people give wealth and goods to a single field of blessings, but because their minds are different, they receive various rewards - some attain the bliss of the three existences, some attain the bliss of quiescence, and some attain the bliss of benefiting others - because their thoughts and vows are superior, they receive different rewards.
Those who create blessings with a mind of love will be foolish and dark when they receive their rewards;
Those who cultivate blessings with a compassionate mind will attain wisdom when they receive their fruits;
Those who create blessings for the benefit of sentient beings without destroying the mind of enlightenment should know that these blessings are the most excellent among blessings;
The other cultivations of blessings are called similar blessings, not the foremost blessings.

Cultivating the wisdom of one flavor should be known as the foremost blessing, because it benefits the world and does not cut off the lineage of the Three Jewels. Knowing karma, knowing its fruits, knowing to take refuge in the Buddha's compassion.
Those who calculate their own merit as if they were doing evil are very shameful. A good man, seeing that the human and heavenly worlds have no savior, never cultivates merit for himself.
The suffering in birth and death is still unbearable to hear, let alone to see with one's own eyes?
Sentient beings receiving bodies are extremely hateful and disgusting. How can one cultivate merit and create karma for oneself?
What the compassionate cannot do.
For a moment, not apart from a compassionate mind, as a close friend of sentient beings, how can one create merit for oneself?

One who has tasted the flavor of merit, having attained mastery, attains the supreme flavor of the reward of others' gratitude. Even in a dream, one does not create merit for oneself, let alone when awake.
With wisdom, one can see the faults and never seeks existence to create merit. The compassionate never create merit for liberation.
The wise abandon the karma of seeking existence, and the compassionate abandon the karma of liberation.
Why is it so?
Because the compassionate, for the sake of benefiting others, create equally without supreme wisdom.
The cause of blessings is one, the fruit of blessings is unequaled, and one attains wisdom from the ten powers.
Abandoning the happiness of benefiting others for one's own happiness is called ingratitude.
Only I can know, and I know from the Buddha, therefore all sentient beings are my companions in cultivating blessings.
If one attains the fruit and enjoys it alone, it is called ingratitude.
How could one enjoy it alone when happiness is so difficult to obtain?
Such a person is abandoned by all.
Even if one attains the bliss of a thousand nirvanas, it is not as beneficial as saving a single sentient being from suffering, which is superior to attaining the bliss of a thousand nirvanas.
One does not enjoy liberation alone.
Why is it so?
Because one sees that sentient beings in the world have no refuge and no savior.
One does not enjoy liberation alone, let alone the unsurpassed enlightenment.

Chapter 17: Liberation by Contemplation There are other samÄdhis, concentrations, wisdom, and realms of sentient beings that are all made into buddhas. Because there is this samÄdhi, one does not wish to attain liberation.
Dhuta removes all faults and evils, and tranquility is like being in the mouth;
The true savior suffers for the sake of sentient beings and therefore does not attain realization.
Concentration, wisdom, and compassion arise by themselves, seeing the various sufferings in the world,
The true savior in the world will never cross over and leave.

Just as the tides of the ocean never go beyond their limits, the practitioner of compassion, even if able to save one person through a hundred kalpas of ascetic practice, will never leave birth and death.
With the power to attain liberation, he remains in birth and death for the sake of sentient beings.

In the three kinds of giving, he is always like a festival at all times, not enjoying his own happiness but making others happy. Day and night, he does not dwell in birth and death, joyfully and happily as if dwelling in nirvÄá¹‡a.

Bodhisattvas always make beneficial actions for sentient beings, and the joy and delight they experience in wisdom is even greater than the joy of liberation. Bodhisattvas find joy and delight in bringing happiness to others.

There are sentient beings who do not experience joy and delight and attain liberation. If wise people attain liberation and know the joy and delight of benefiting others, they will certainly return to benefit sentient beings.

Those who fear saá¹ƒsÄra and seek liberation for their own benefit consider it to be ultimate bliss, but it is not as joyful and blissful as the bodhisattvas' delight in benefiting others while accepting the aggregates of the body.ğŸ”½If one experiences suffering and oppression oneself, one may enter nirvÄá¹‡a. But all sentient beings experience suffering and oppression, so how can one abandon sentient beings and enter nirvÄá¹‡a?

Those who see their own suffering and enter nirvÄá¹‡a, the compassionate ones see the suffering of all sentient beings residing in their own minds. How can they abandon sentient beings and enter nirvÄá¹‡a?
If one is able to bring joy to others, that is nirvÄá¹‡a. If it is not so, then it is saá¹ƒsÄra.
For one who has impartial compassion for sentient beings, bringing joy to others is nirvÄá¹‡a, as praised by the Buddha.
If liberation is like the joy of benefiting a single person, it is loved by the wise. If one bestows great joy to others without regard for one's own efforts, that is liberation.
The compassionate one brings joy to others without expecting reward. If one is able to do so, that is liberation. If it is not so, then it is saá¹ƒsÄra.
If one seeks joy for oneself, that is suffering. Abandoning one's own joy and seeking joy for others is nirvÄá¹‡a.
Worldly beings call it liberation because it destroys suffering. Cultivating compassion is able to destroy the suffering of others, which is the supreme liberation.
Destroying the suffering of others brings joy to both. What wise person would abandon two liberations and take one liberation?
Worldly people say:
The wise attain liberation.
The Bodhisattva thinks like this:
I do not believe these words.
How could a wise person abandon the joy of saving others and attain liberation for their own joy?
Being able to bring joy to others, the joy in the three realms surpasses the joy of liberation.
The Bodhisattva's suffering for the sake of sentient beings is greater than others' attainment of the joy of liberation for themselves.
Chapter 18: Benefiting Others. Sentient beings in the world, for the sake of their own joy, are physically and mentally exhausted in birth and death;

The Bodhisattva's mind finds rest. With a compassionate mind, benefiting others, in birth and death, apart from the Dharma of counteraction, there is no joy. Apart from benefiting others, the Bodhisattva has no joy.

Bodhisattvas attain the joy of benefiting others, knowing that benefiting others is precisely benefiting oneself. They abandon their own self-benefit and love the joy of benefiting others, knowing that their own joy is precisely the joy of benefiting others, and knowing that the joy of benefiting others is precisely their own joy, because when they know the joy of benefiting others, it is precisely their own joy.
There are three kinds of people: superior, middling, and inferior.
Foolish people see others' happiness and give rise to distress in their minds.
Middling people, when they themselves are suffering, know that others are suffering.
Superior people, when they see others happy, give rise to joy in their minds, and when they see others suffering, they are as if suffering themselves.
The four means of embracing others in the bodhisattva's practice are the same as one's own benefit.
What is meant by the same benefit?
Others' suffering is suffering, and others' happiness is happiness. This is called the same benefit.
Compassion is impartial and has no other thoughts. Bodhisattvas share in the suffering and happiness of sentient beings, and the bodhisattvas themselves give rise to special suffering and distress.
Why is this?
Because they are unable to save sentient beings from suffering.

Not observing the past, not observing the future, according with the intentions of the multitude to create the antidotes to the cessation of suffering, the bodhisattva's own mind is also like the minds of others.
Worldly beings benefit and bring happiness to others while expecting something in return, but the bodhisattva benefits and brings happiness to others without expecting anything in return.

Although the bodhisattva's mind of compassion is impartial and loves all beings equally, he still brings happiness and benefit to those who hate him to an even greater extent. When he brings happiness and benefit to those who hate him, his mind is filled with joy.
The joy of giving up one's life is called impartiality. If it is not like this, it is called partiality.
Bringing happiness and benefit to those who hate him to an even greater extent is called the activity of the mind of compassion.
The bodhisattva gives rise to a mind of compassion equally towards all beings, but he has even greater pity for those who engage in evil conduct.
It is like a wealthy elder who has only one child, his love and concern for whom penetrates to the very marrow of his bones;
the bodhisattva's love and concern for all beings is also like this.

It is like a bad child who does not want his father to surpass him. This is called ingratitude. All resentful and hateful sentient beings are of the same flavor of evil towards the bodhisattva, but the bodhisattva gives rise to a compassionate mind of the same flavor towards resentful and hateful sentient beings.
Sentient beings in the world who receive gratitude give rise to joy. If the bodhisattva bestows benefit and happiness upon resentful and hateful sentient beings, the joy in his mind surpasses this.
When sentient beings in the world are scolded, if the other does not respond in kind, they are greatly delighted.
When the bodhisattva is scolded by others, his mind is greatly delighted.
Those with a loving mind are universally present throughout the three realms. The compassionate mind of the bodhisattva is also universally present throughout the three realms.
The bodhisattva has compassion for sentient beings in hell, but not as much compassion for sentient beings attached to and deluded by the three realms.

Sentient beings are bound by immeasurable great suffering for the sake of their own happiness, and the bodhisattva is bound by immeasurable great suffering for the sake of benefiting and bringing happiness to others.
All sentient beings have the same goal, which is to leave suffering and attain happiness, and to benefit and bring happiness to others is the supreme conditioned [existence].

Those who benefit themselves are also the cause of compassion and the cause of joy. Those who benefit others see it and give rise to compassion and joy. Because they benefit themselves, they give rise to compassion. Seeing others attain happiness, they rejoice.
The four immeasurable minds are the inner mind wishing to cultivate the four means of gathering [disciples]. Benefiting and bringing happiness to sentient beings is called the supreme [means].
Cultivating the four immeasurables can bestow both worldly and supramundane dharmas. The worldly dharmas, supramundane dharmas, and the four immeasurables all have the same realm.
Why is this?
Because they equally benefit sentient beings and equally attain the fruit of unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Those who have compassion can benefit others, and those who have wisdom can let go, not giving rise to a mind of rarity or a mind of high and low.

Chapter 19: Outshining the Suffering of Others Chapter 19: Outshining the Suffering of Others When bodhisattvas see the suffering of others, it is the greatest suffering for the bodhisattvas themselves. When they see the joy of others, it is the greatest joy for the bodhisattvas themselves. For this reason, bodhisattvas always benefit others.
Foolish beings, when they see the suffering of others, take it as their own joy. They see the suffering of others but do not consider it suffering;
The wise take their own suffering as joy and bring joy to others, not taking their own suffering.
Foolish beings, for their own slight joy, bring great suffering to others;
The wise, in order to bring slight joy to others, undergo great suffering themselves.

Evil doers cultivate causes for slight joy and attain great joy. Although they experience delight, it is not as great as the bodhisattvas' great delight in benefiting others with slight joy, which surpasses it many times over.
Bodhisattvas see others suffering and take it upon themselves. Although their bodies suffer, they do not consider it suffering. In their minds, they are overjoyed and experience great delight.
The bodhisattva's compassionate mind attains mastery and joy, not being oppressed by the sufferings of the three realms of existence.
Because the bodhisattva drinks the sweet dew of compassion, he is not afflicted by suffering, and because he is not afflicted by suffering, he is able to suffer for others.
When ordinary foolish beings see the suffering of others, their minds give rise to joy; when they see the happiness of others, their minds give rise to suffering.
When the bodhisattva sees the suffering of others, he suffers; when he sees their happiness, he is happy.

Those without a compassionate mind, when seeing the suffering of others, are as cold as the moon; those with a compassionate mind, when seeing others undergoing suffering, are like the scorching sun in summer.
Whether it be the foolish or the wise, when seeing the suffering of others, they all give rise to aversion and the causes of sorrow and distress;
Those with a compassionate mind deeply feel pity and make a resolute mind, that the suffering of all beings is their own suffering.
The bodhisattva thinks:
If one is unable to give rise to great diligence, by what means can one destroy this great suffering?
The bodhisattva shares the same benefits and sufferings as all sentient beings, and must diligently strive to attain enlightenment.
The bodhisattva thinks:
After I attain enlightenment, I will give it to all sentient beings and return to the cycle of birth and death.
From the initial arousal of the mind to the attainment of enlightenment, I will again give it to sentient beings, but it cannot be obtained.
In order to benefit others, the bodhisattva practices the four means of gathering disciples without ever becoming weary, just as the great earth supports all things without ever becoming weary.
For one's own sake, even if one enjoys happiness, one still becomes weary. The bodhisattva acts for the sake of others and creates joy without becoming weary.
The bodhisattva acts for the sake of others and sees the suffering of AvÄ«ci as the bliss of nirvÄá¹‡a. What weariness is there on the other side of suffering?
If one experiences happiness for the sake of a single sentient being and oneself experiences immeasurable hell, one always acts with vigor and creates joy for others without becoming weary.
For what reason does one act for the sake of others and create joy without becoming weary?
Bodhisattvas observe all sentient beings and do not see them as different from themselves.
Sentient beings, attached to afflictions, wish to harm others in all situations;
Those who are upheld by compassion wish to experience all suffering.
Bodhisattvas experience the suffering of oppression for others, just as those who suffer wish for the bliss of liberation.

When bodhisattvas delight in experiencing the suffering of oppression on behalf of others, the mind of great compassion is purified. With wisdom, they observe others experiencing suffering, and the compassionate mind abides within that. Where the compassionate mind abides, suffering cannot abide.
Although the compassionate one is bound by the suffering of all sentient beings, such a mind that benefits and delights others gives rise to joy, surpassing the bliss of liberation.
Bodhisattvas see the suffering of others as their own suffering, and wish to give the bliss they experience to others, realizing it to be superior to nirvana.
The compassionate one always wishes to experience their suffering themselves and give the bliss to others. Compassion and suffering cannot abide together for even a single moment.
When those who do evil see others suffering, they want to avoid them from afar. When they see others obtaining happiness, their minds are not joyful.
When bodhisattvas see others suffering, they do not want to be far away from them. Those without love have no suffering karma.
Why is this?
Because they give rise to great joy in eliminating the suffering of others.
Bodhisattvas do not necessarily rejoice in giving others great happiness, but they are greatly delighted to see others giving people a little happiness.
Why is this?
Because it is their nature.
Bodhisattvas see others obtaining happiness and themselves also being happy. When bodhisattvas see people giving others a little happiness, why would they not give rise to joy?
Chapter 20: Love and Compassion If a person does not know that their body and mind are always bound by extreme suffering, then they cannot know the suffering in others' minds.

Those without compassion do no evil. If they see others' misfortune and their minds are not softened, this person is called an extremely evil practitioner. If there is a heavy debt of gratitude, when can they repay it?
When a person is about to die, even delicious medicine is considered extremely painful, and they engage in extremely evil conduct.
Those without merit and virtue regard the sweet medicine of compassion as extremely painful.
If a person is very wealthy and has abundant treasures, but only eats and uses them themselves and does not give to others, they are criticized by others.
Even if one has wisdom and much learning, if they lack a compassionate mind, they are also ridiculed and criticized by others.
If one sees suffering sentient beings and is unable to generate a compassionate mind, they are not a vessel of merit, just like a broken vessel cannot hold water.

Those with a compassionate mind, even if unable to rescue suffering sentient beings, can at least lament, Alas, sentient beings! They see sentient beings afflicted by the illnesses of greed, anger, and delusion, and the sufferings of birth, aging, sickness, and death, constantly tormented by various sufferings.
Strange, sentient beings fall into such great suffering!
Sentient beings in the world suffer physically and mentally, constantly destroyed by afflictions and karma.
Alas, how strange!
What suffering of oppression in the world would not cause a bodhisattva to give rise to compassion?
The body dwells in the swift current, sinking in the endless and fearful great ocean of birth and death.

Sentient beings are always suffering from the suffering of suffering, the suffering of change, and the suffering of conditioned existence. If seeing a single suffering is enough to give rise to the cause of compassion, how much more so when fully endowed with the three sufferings?

Foolish sentient beings are always suffering from hundreds of thousands of sufferings. If seeing a single suffering should give rise to a compassionate mind, how much more so when there are hundreds of thousands of sufferings?

One should understand the sufferings of the world, and within each suffering, where compassion has not yet arisen, it should be given rise to; where compassion has already arisen, it should be increased, how much more so when there are immeasurable [sufferings]?
If one hears of the various immeasurable sufferings in the world, even stone should become soft, how much more so a sentient being who does not give rise to compassion?
If one hears the cries of suffering in the world, even a withered tree should produce flowers, how much more so a sentient being who does not give rise to compassion?
The suffering of the world is of one taste. Those with a tender mind easily give rise to compassion. Those with compassion have the fruit of enlightenment in the palm of their hand.
Compassion is extremely abundant, and benefiting others already produces joy.
The poor person with compassion cannot crave this joy.
The ignorant love self-mastery, and compassion then turns away.
When compassion has turned away, all suffering gathers.
The one who loves self-mastery, dwelling in birth and death, wishes to share suffering with others and revolve in birth and death;
The one with compassion, for the beings of the world, shares the bliss of cessation with them and departs.
One with a mind of love delights in the three existences. One who knows the faults of love delights in nirvana. One who benefits others delights in compassion.
The one who loves self-mastery always delights in the world, because taking on a body is for one's own happiness;
The one who has mastery over compassion always delights in taking on a body, because it is for the happiness of others.

Those who are self-bound by their own happiness always wish to give happiness to others, while those who are self-bound by their own happiness are always weary of their own happiness. Those who are self-bound by their own happiness are always weary of giving happiness to others.
The foolish love little and do not love themselves or others, but bodhisattvas also love themselves.
The foolish beings who always act for the self actually act for others.

Chapter 22: The Great Man The bodhisattva's compassionate mind is only oppressed by one thing, which is always being oppressed by the suffering of others' affairs, and there is no other thing. This is called accomplishing the aggregate of compassion.
Abandoning nirvÄá¹‡a as if abandoning suffering, and accepting the body as if taking liberation, giving benefit and joy to the world is called compassion.
Knowing the merits of nirvÄá¹‡a and the faults of saá¹ƒsÄra, yet not abandoning conditioned phenomena, all of this is the merit of great compassion.
Being detached from all places, taking nirvana as the essence but not grasping nirvana, is called a hero.

For the sake of great compassion, one is able to enter birth and death, going and coming, observing the exhaustion and cessation of existence, knowing that sentient beings are suffering, saving and relying on them, holding great compassion in the mind, despising one's own body and seeking the body of the ten powers, attaining the place of great compassion, the place of compassion, and merit.
Just as a wheel-turning sage king, although having a thousand sons, still loves the one with excellent features;
The Buddha is also like this, loving those with compassion among all sentient beings.

Only being able to create blessings, without wisdom and compassion, is called a man. Having blessings and wisdom is called a good man. If one cultivates blessings, compassion, and wisdom, he is called a great man.
One should look at the compassionate one. One with compassion should speak and pay respect to the compassionate one, who possesses all merits.
Chapter 23: Explaining Compassion The people, gods, and asuras of the world experience various sufferings in their bodies.
Only bodhisattvas have compassion that penetrates to the bone marrow, knowing that compassion is foremost among all wholesome dharmas.
The wise should know that just as all letters begin with the syllable a, all wholesome dharmas are included within compassion.
Just as all colors are included in a single house, if one sees the purity of space, one sees the purity of great compassion. Seeing the boundlessness of space, great compassion is also boundless.
The Buddha said:
If you wish to see me directly, you should revere great compassion;
if you wish to see me, you should observe that all beings in the three realms are suffering.
Because suffering is boundless, great compassion is also boundless; because suffering abides, great compassion also abides.
Where does great compassion abide?
Abiding in the various sufferings of all sentient beings, such as greed, anger, delusion, birth, old age, sickness, and death, dwelling there with their relatives.
Having a mind of great compassion, able to know the suffering of others, this is called dwelling together with the Buddha.
There are three kinds of giving that nourish all merits, like a wet-nurse, this is called great compassion.
Just as the snow mountains give birth to all medicines, the snow mountain of great compassion gives birth to three kinds of giving.
Apart from compassion, there is no Dharma that can bring happiness to the world;
Giving, which is the essence of compassion, can bring various kinds of happiness to the world.
The unsurpassed fruition is accomplished by the three kinds of giving, and compassion is the cause of the three kinds of giving.
The grandmother of sentient beings is able to give birth to the TathÄgata. Whom among all sentient beings, the most supreme and unsurpassed, would not revere?
Being able to give birth to the three kinds of giving is called great compassion.
The bodhisattva's great compassion and merit are extremely abundant, abiding in the mind, with only one thing not being far removed, without attachment, always benefiting others without weariness.

Worldly and supramundane happiness, as well as the happiness of benefiting others, all arise from compassion. Therefore, I now respect compassion, the one who can benefit the world and has great compassion.
I also respect various merits, which are indeed as described, with two merits being supreme:
Being able to benefit others and purifying one's own compassion.ğŸ”½Compassion can purify giving, therefore I now love and respect it;
Giving can adorn compassion, I also love and respect it;
Compassion and those who share the same sound of compassion, I also love and respect.

Compassion can purify the essence of the mind, giving can purify the path of karma, being able to purify the essence of the mind and being able to purify the path of karma, then one can purify the path to nirvana and purify the path to unsurpassed enlightenment.
Compassion can purify renunciation, those without compassion are defiled in their renunciation.
Generosity can purify compassion, and compassion can purify generosity. This is called uprightness in the world.
Compassion can give rise to faith and respect, just as the earth is adorned with various flowers;
Great compassion is also like this.

Sentient beings in the world are scorched by the sun of afflictions. Those who attain the mind of compassion all give rise to cool bliss, just as in the hot summer when one obtains a cool breeze and all attain relief.

The chapter on the superiority of loving-kindness and compassion, the twenty-fifth. The conditions of attachment arise from craving, and with craving there is attachment and without craving there is no attachment;

Where there is compassion there is giving, and where there is no compassion there is also no giving.ğŸ”½Because of craving, attachment increases, and because of giving, compassion increases.ğŸ”½Loving those with affection gives rise to love, and this harm and resentment increases the compassionate mind.
Increasing love for one's own happiness harms others, while increasing compassion can bring happiness to others and oneself suffers;
It is not rare for one who increases attachment and harms others, but it is rare for one with a compassionate mind to give up one's own life and give it to others.
One who is attached is called a foolish and lowly person, always in poverty and suffering;
One with the merit of compassion always lives in wealth and nobility.
One who is greedy can be cut off, and when one is content, one can attain wisdom and cut off contentment;
One who attains a compassionate mind is never content, always giving to others.
The mind of attachment can attract all suffering and form a great mass of suffering, while the mind of compassion can give rise to all merits.
If compassion does not abandon impure karma, I do not desire it;
Even if compassion cannot save, I do not desire it either;
If compassion does not delight in seeking enlightenment, it is also not what I desire.
The mind of attachment can give rise to all suffering, while the mind of compassion can give rise to all happiness.
The physical and verbal actions arising from compassion are called supreme actions, for the compassionate mind can bring inexhaustible happiness to all sentient beings.
In the chapter on wisdom, compassion, and liberation, the twenty-sixth chapter, which of the two things, wisdom and compassion, is superior?

The wise can only take refuge in themselves, but the compassionate can cause others to take refuge in the unsurpassed way.ğŸ”½Having compassion but lacking wisdom is not loved by the wise, and having wisdom but lacking compassion is also not loved by the wise, as it obstructs the unsurpassed way.
Wisdom not accompanied by a compassionate mind can obstruct the wisdom of the unsurpassed way, which bodhisattvas consider to be a lack of wisdom.
Not delighting in samsara for a single moment, compassion does not wish for liberation.

The taste of liberation is like nectar, but the compassionate consider it to be tasteless, just as delicious food without salt is considered tasteless. Although liberation is sweet, if it lacks a compassionate mind, bodhisattvas consider it to be tasteless.
If great compassion is different from liberation, then all liberations should be respectfully paid homage to, because great compassion is the mother of all Buddhas.
Liberation is called the eternal extinction of all things without remainder.
Compassion is like a good spell that can revive the dead.

If one accepts a body with continuous continuity, it is the error of permanence; if one grasps liberation, it is the error of annihilation. The Buddha is called the savior of all beings because he is free from these two extremes.
If there were no Buddha, there would be no liberation; if there were no compassion, there would also be no attainment of Buddhahood.
Compassion can give rise to liberation. For this reason, the bodhisattva takes compassion.
Compassion is a single thing that can perform two functions:
First, it can save sentient beings;
Second, it can give rise to the Buddha's wisdom.
Chapter 27: Making Vows The bodhisattva thinks:
All sentient beings share immeasurable kinds of suffering.
I should arouse the mind of compassion and attain omniscience to extinguish the immeasurable suffering shared by all sentient beings.
The bodhisattva sees all sentient beings sinking in the immeasurable and boundless sea of birth and death, and attains the mind of impartial compassion.
The ignorant and foolish ones who delight in liberation give rise to a mind of abandonment.
The great mass of suffering in the world gives rise to my supreme mind of compassion.

The bodhisattva contemplates, I have the mind of compassion and observe the suffering sentient beings who have not attained the path of enlightenment. How can I enable sentient beings to attain the path of liberation?
The bodhisattva contemplates:
I am the least fortunate in the entire world. I am now unable to save sentient beings.
The bodhisattva contemplates:
I am a great friend to the sentient beings in the three realms, yet sentient beings are constantly afflicted by physical suffering and mental suffering. I am now called an empty and evil survivor.
The bodhisattva contemplates:
If I cannot destroy the suffering of the world and cannot benefit sentient beings, what is the use of my receiving this body?
The Bodhisattva thinks:
I am a close friend to all sentient beings. I should nurture and bring great benefit to even my enemies.
The Bodhisattva thinks:
All sentient beings can perform dignified deeds for me, and I will not allow a single sentient being to have an undignified intention.
The Bodhisattva thinks like this:
As for benefiting others, seeking the characteristics of other people is completely unattainable, completely like oneself.
What is it?
Benefiting others is precisely benefiting oneself.
The Bodhisattva thinks:

If there is a place that can be wished for, I will cause the physical and mental suffering of all sentient beings to gather in my body all at once, and I will always receive it for them, causing sentient beings to attain happiness without considering it suffering.
The Bodhisattva thinks:
I will endure all the sufferings that arise on the path to my enlightenment.
Why is this so?
Because I cannot liberate sentient beings who are drowning in the sea of suffering of birth and death.
The Bodhisattva thinks:
Although there are heavy afflictions, the path to enlightenment is difficult to attain.
In this way, I only have compassion and wisdom as my companions, and my mind will never be weary.
The Bodhisattva thinks:
The path practiced by the Well-Gone Ones, I now depart from it;
I now, in the world, give compassion to sentient beings.
I should think of myself as no different from them.
The Bodhisattva thinks:

I am now the refuge and savior of the world. I should give rise to a great vow and cultivate the great adornments. Wisdom is my good companion. Now, the sprout of the Buddha's wisdom is about to grow.
The Bodhisattva thinks:
I wish to extinguish the suffering of sentient beings, to enable all sentient beings to attain happiness, to do the deeds of all sentient beings, I am always instructed by the mind of compassion.
The Bodhisattva thinks:

The suffering of birth and death is so much so that even hearing about it is exhausting and detestable, but the compassionate one is able to endure the suffering of the world, therefore, for the sake of the mind of compassion, one still faces the door of birth and death.
The Bodhisattva thinks:
The suffering of birth and death is extremely detestable, I wish to enter nirvana.
Great compassion says:
Sentient beings who are suffering have not yet been liberated, how can you abandon them and leave?
The Bodhisattva thinks:
The conditioned suffering is complete, the happiness of leaving the world is nirvana.
I now know that the conditioned suffering of birth and death and the unconditioned happiness of nirvana, the mind of compassion always happily gives the three kinds of gifts.
The Bodhisattva thinks:
I am very afraid of all existences, but for the sake of saving sentient beings with the mind of compassion, I happily dwell in all existences.
The mind of compassion says to the Bodhisattva:
I have you dwell in birth and death, and will never let you go.
Why is it so?
It is for the sake of repaying kindness.
The Bodhisattva thought:

The bliss of liberation, for the sake of liberating sentient beings, I do not even wish to eat. Compassion prevents me from obtaining food, let alone the bliss of the impermanent and unstable birth and death.
The Bodhisattva thought:
Among all kinds of bliss, the Buddha says that nirvana is the foremost.
Although nirvana is blissful, my wisdom does not wish to leave.
The reason my wisdom does not wish to leave is because of the union with compassion.
The Bodhisattva thought:
I now respect and value nirvana.
Why is it so?
Because in nirvana there is no birth, old age, sickness, or death.
Although nirvana is blissful, I am pulled by compassion and cannot leave for the sake of sentient beings.
Compassion is the mother of all Buddhas, and therefore I do not abandon it and head towards nirvana.
If nirvana is still not realized even if it is based on the self, how much more so if one abandons sentient beings and turns to nirvana?
The Bodhisattva thought:
I want to turn to nirvana, but compassion is the mother of the Buddha, giving me milk.
How can I abandon it and head for supreme enlightenment?
Even if I do not seek to benefit and bring joy to sentient beings, how much more so if I seek nirvana?
The Bodhisattva thought:
I should not turn to nirvana, because I abandon sentient beings who have no refuge.
Because of the compassionate mind, I do not realize nirvana.
Nirvana is the end of birth and death. If there is no birth, how can I save sentient beings?
The Bodhisattva thought:
There are two kinds of joy in taking rebirth:
One is the joy of saving sentient beings, and the other is the joy of liberation.
How can I abandon two kinds of joy and take one kind of joy?
The Bodhisattva thought:
All ordinary beings together possess the nature of omniscience, and omniscience is easy for ordinary beings to attain.
For this reason, I love ordinary beings and do not love liberation.
The bodhisattva thinks:
Wherever there are suffering beings, the mind of compassion can arise and compassion can grow.
For this reason, I love existence.
The bodhisattva says to the mind of compassion:
You cause me to attain purity and growth, and cause all beings to attain purity and attain growth.
The bodhisattva says to the mind of compassion:
Beings are in suffering, oppressed by hundreds of thousands of sufferings.
Today, cause beings to surely attain happiness, and accomplish this matter with me.
The bodhisattva says to the mind of compassion:
Beings are bound by craving and are controlled by death.
Seeing the world without refuge or support, in order to save beings, they undergo various sufferings.
The Bodhisattva thought:
I love the Great Man. Seeing sentient beings falling into suffering, I abandon the bliss of nirvana and strive for the sake of bringing peace and happiness to sentient beings.
The Bodhisattva thought:
Those who have saved sentient beings, attained the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas, attained the definitive wisdom, and attained the prediction, I now make offerings and pay homage to them.
The Bodhisattva thought:
The Buddha has attained the pure eye. May I join my palms and request the Buddha to give me the prediction.
Chapter 28: Making the Same Vow, the Buddhas of the Ten Directions Appear Before One for the Sake of Saving Sentient Beings. I Now Make the Bodhi Resolve:
All the deeds done by sentient beings, I am now able to do for them.
The Buddhas' great compassion all praises us well.
All my wisdom and blessings, may I liberate those who have no refuge.
The World-Honored One has always made me dislike the mind of little wisdom. The World-Honored One has made me possess the ten powers like the World-Honored One.

If the raging fire of afflictions burns the minds of sentient beings, I will use the water of the Dharma to extinguish the raging fire of afflictions in sentient beings, destroy the enemies of Mara, attain wise understanding, turn the wheel of the Dharma, and eliminate all the suffering and distress of sentient beings.
I will turn the wheel of the Dharma for all sentient beings at the same time, and all the blessings I create are for this purpose.
With this merit, may I attain the supreme Dharma body, like empty space pervading everywhere, and attain the two kinds of bodies to teach and transform the world;
May my blessings merge with those of the Buddhas, and may the helpless sentient beings attain liberation.

The various afflictions create suffering with different characteristics and can cause suffering. I will use my wisdom to eliminate the suffering of sentient beings. May I use this merit to fill the realm of space with a single taste of bliss for all sentient beings, and may I always fulfill my wishes.
The thieves of the five hindrances and five aggregates can rob one's merits. May I use this merit to rescue and protect all sentient beings from the fear of death in the world.

As long as the world exists, may my wholesome dharmas also abide. Because of my wholesomeness, may all worlds, both mundane and supramundane, be free from suffering and attain happiness, and may all sentient beings always be in harmony at the same time.
The Bodhisattva thought:
From now on, I will always follow the requests of beggars and accept their instructions;
From now on, may all sentient beings deeply trust my body and not give rise to other thoughts. May I provide them with whatever they desire and satisfy their needs.
The Bodhisattva thought:
May I, from now until I attain enlightenment, not have a single body that does not see the Buddha.
The bodhisattva thinks:
May I, from now on, in the long course of birth and death, if I do not see the Buddha, may I not be separated from the compassionate mind for even a single moment.
The bodhisattva thinks:

May I, until I reach the point of becoming a Buddha, see the various sufferings endured by sentient beings outside, and may I take them all upon myself, causing my body to experience bone-piercing compassion, causing my body to attain the wisdom and liberation of a Buddha.
The bodhisattva thinks:
May my compassionate mind be like empty space.
All mountains, rivers, trees, birds, and beasts all depend on space to exist. All sentient beings at all times enter my compassion.
I rely on all sentient beings to establish good roots. With this goodness of mine, I give it back to all sentient beings to attain the fruit of liberation.
All roads, bridges, boats, and places are shared by all sentient beings. May all my virtues also be shared by all sentient beings.
The bodhisattva thinks:
Earth, water, fire, and wind are shared by all sentient beings. May the virtues I cultivate be shared by all sentient beings.
May I use the wholesome roots I obtain because of all sentient beings to give to all sentient beings and attain unobstructed wisdom.
The bodhisattva thinks:

May the virtues I create cause all sentient beings to leave the realm of MÄra and enter the realm of the Buddha. May I attain wisdom and always have the Buddha's wisdom manifest before me, the ten perfections. May all sentient beings obtain peaceful and happy bliss and attain an unshakable mind.
May all sentient beings mutually rescue and help each other in their calamities and afflictions.
The bodhisattva says to the merit and virtue:
All sentient beings are obstructed by ignorance and do not know their own suffering and the suffering of others. You should open and explain this to them.
When a bodhisattva practices giving by offering clean water, may all sentient beings eliminate the thirst of afflictive bonds and attain the supreme path of compassion.
When I offer water, may I enable all sentient beings to be free from the servitude of affection and love, to always attain self-mastery, and to obtain the wealth of the Dharma.

May my blessings be like a river, my compassionate mind be like a flower without defilements, my precepts be like the bottom, and my giving be like a swift flowing stream, eliminating the suffering of thirst for sentient beings.
May my mind of compassion always be like a great river.
The bodhisattva contemplates:

May my mind of compassion be like an ocean, my pure precepts be like the ocean tides, my forbearance be like the waves, my wisdom be like the movements of ocean creatures, and my compassionate mind be like the water of a single flavor.

Whatever I offer, may it become an ocean of compassionate mind, may the blessings of giving obtain the sweetness of compassion, and may it eliminate the birth, old age, sickness, and death of sentient beings.

Chapter 29: The Vow of Supreme Aspiration If I arouse the mind of compassion for all beings and bring them benefit and joy, may my great compassion be firm, and may compassion extinguish the suffering of beings.
May all the suffering of beings come to afflict me.
May I now, with the merit of this gift of fearlessness, enable all beings to attain great compassion.
May the merit of my patience and forbearance in the future, during the age of warfare, enable my compassion to extinguish the anger of all beings.
By the merit of giving food, during the famine, may I obtain food and drink to satisfy all beings;
By the merit of giving water to beings, may I accomplish the compassionate mind, abiding in the hearts of all beings;
By the merit of giving clothing to beings, may all beings attain the mind of shame and remorse;
By the merit of offering lamps to the Buddha, may I in the future obtain the sun of the Buddha to extinguish all darkness;
By the merit of giving my eyes, may all sentient beings in the future quickly attain the Buddha's eye;
By the merit of giving my head, may all sentient beings turn towards the mind of enlightenment;
By the merit of the causes and conditions of giving medicine, may all sentient beings eliminate birth, old age, sickness, and death;
By the merit of the causes and conditions of serving and attending to sentient beings, may all sentient beings attain the unsurpassed, undefiled, and accomplish the path to enlightenment;
By the merit of the causes and conditions of offering flowers, banners, and canopies to the Buddha's stupa, may all sentient beings attain exalted blessings;
By the merit of the causes and conditions of offering banners to the relics, may all sentient beings eliminate darkness and attain illumination;
By the causes and conditions of offering the sound of bells, may all sentient beings attain the voice of Brahma;
By the merit of the causes and conditions of offering incense, flowers, and necklaces, may all sentient beings eliminate the defilements, afflictions, and foul odors of the bonds and afflictions;
By the merit and virtue of making offerings to the Three Jewels, may all sentient beings always encounter the Three Jewels without interruption;
By the merit and virtue of removing the fear of dangerous paths for merchants and traders, may all sentient beings be free from the fear of birth and death;
By the merit and virtue of rescuing sentient beings from the danger of the ocean, may all sentient beings cross the ocean of birth and death;
By the merit and virtue of my pure wholesome causes and conditions, may all sentient beings destroy the four demons and attain perfect enlightenment.

When I attain supreme enlightenment, although I speak this way for the sake of sentient beings, in order to comfort sentient beings I speak these words. By this merit and virtue, may all sentient beings attain supreme enlightenment. The enlightenment of all sentient beings is my enlightenment.

All sentient beings are obstructed by delusion. May they attain supreme enlightenment. By this cause and condition and merit and virtue, may all sentient beings attain Buddhahood before me, and I will attain it last.
May the merits and virtues of my going back and forth in the cycle of birth and death enable all sentient beings to attain Buddhahood;
May the merits and virtues of my arousing the good mind cause all sentient beings to attain the wisdom of the Buddha.
Those who see, hear, uphold, recite, and chant will all plant the causes for unsurpassed enlightenment.

I wish to fulfill the desires and aspirations of all sentient beings. My vow is not yet fulfilled. If I see suffering sentient beings crying out in grief, with these merits, may I enable all sentient beings to attain Buddhahood and joyfully behold it.
If I cultivate various wholesome practices but do not enable all sentient beings to attain Buddhahood, I would not even be happy to hear of it, let alone actually do it.
The Bodhisattva said to Gongde:
If you cannot protect sentient beings and be their reliance, I also do not wish for you or your rewards.
Why is it so?
It is because I cultivate blessings for the sake of sentient beings, not for myself.
If sentient beings are exhausted, my goodness is like empty space, and in the three times I give sentient beings happiness, bestowing the mind of enlightenment.

The vow of compassion of the supreme hero is called the mind of compassion, also called the five kinds of teachings, also called saving sentient beings, and is collectively called the practice of the great man.
(The wise have five hundred verses, and ancient books have eight hundred.
The master, the son of the bull, Tiparada, a great bodhisattva, was born in the south, and this is the end of his work.)
